subject: Cybersecurity
title: Stuxnet: The Weapon That Changed Warfare
description: A quick, practical guide to Stuxnet: The Weapon That Changed Warfare.

hook.text: In 2010, a computer virus physically destroyed nuclear centrifuges in an Iranian facility.

buildup.text: Stuxnet targeted Siemens industrial controllers. It made centrifuges spin at wrong speeds while showing normal readings.

discovery.text: It used four zero-day exploits â€” an unprecedented arsenal. It was clearly built by a nation-state.

twist.text: Stuxnet was later attributed to the U.S. and Israel. It was the first known cyber weapon to cause physical damage.

climax.text: Stuxnet proved that code can be as destructive as bombs â€” and harder to attribute.

punchline.text: The first cyber weapon didn't steal data. It broke things.
